title: Elected leaders point fingers as Brooklyn park funding evaporates
text:
Whether the $12 million originally promised will ever resurface is uncertain. | AP Photo Elected leaders point fingers as Brooklyn park funding evaporates

Promised funding for two Brooklyn parks that never materialized has become the center of a political squabble.

In the midst of a contentious reelection campaign, Sen. Marty Golden promised $12 million to revitalize two parks in Brooklyn. After he lost, the money never emerged, as first reported by the Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

Story Continued Below

Why that is depends on who you ask.

Senate Republican Leader John Flanagan has blamed the city for not filling out forms to receive the promised grants — an assertion he reiterated in a scathing Friday statement. A spokesperson for the Senate Democrats said Golden announced funds that never existed. The city has given credence to the Democrats’ claim — a spokesperson for the city parks department said the agency can’t verify that $4 million in funding ever existed and can’t speak to the rest of the money, as the department was not the intended grantee.

As various factions point the finger, there’s no indication the planned upgrades will ever get done — and local officials say that’s the true shame.

“We don’t get a lot of love out here when it comes to City Hall caring about our parks,” said Council Member Justin Brannan, a Democrat who represents the district where one of the parks is located. “When you have parks and playgrounds that have needed renovations for 20, 30 years, it’s a really big deal.”

The funding was meant to go toward rehabilitating a playground at Marine Park and a new ballfield at Shore Road Park.

Flanagan insists city parks “dropped the ball.”

“These awards come from capital money controlled by the Majority,” Flanagan said. “It was incumbent upon the Parks Department to do one simple thing: fill out a form which was sent from Senator Golden’s office to the agency and send it back to receive millions of dollars to fix these parks.”

He added any assertion the money didn’t exist is “egregious,” accusing the new Senate majority of “perpetuating lies.”

A spokesperson for Senate Democrats pushed back, adding it’s on Golden for not doing more to ensure the money would materialize during his final days in office.

"No amount of rambling nonsense can change the facts,” said Gary Ginsburg, a spokesperson for the Senate Democrats. “Marty Golden announced funds that didn’t exist. You can't celebrate graduating from Harvard if all you've done is look at a preliminary application. After Marty lost, he spent his last months in office sulking instead of doing anything to secure those funds.”

Crystal Howard, a spokesperson for the parks department, said the agency has been “unable to verify that the $4 million existed for the agency to receive.” That money would have gone toward the Marine Park project.

“To our knowledge we did not receive a nomination letter from the senator for the funds that would have precipitated the process,” Howard said.

Howard said she can’t speak to the other $8 million for Shore Road Park, as the department was not the intended recipient.

“It is our understanding that the $8 million that was promised was to be allocated to the Shore Road Parks Conservancy to manage capital projects in the park, not to [the department],” she said.

There is $10.3 million being invested in Marine Park for separate renovation projects, including a new playground expected to be completed in spring 2020 and a new pedestrian path.

But for now, whether the $12 million originally promised will ever resurface is uncertain.

“We enjoy a collaborative relationship with local elected officials and look forward to working with them to improve Marine Park and other Brooklyn parks,” Howard said.
description: As various factions point the finger, there’s no indication the planned upgrades will ever get done.
